trimester_specific_notes.first_trimester: If you exercised before pregnancy, you can generally continue. Fatigue and nausea are common. Listen to your body.
trimester_specific_notes.second_trimester: Often the 'golden period' with most energy. This program is designed for weeks 13-28. After week 16, avoid lying flat on back.
trimester_specific_notes.third_trimester: Reduce intensity and depth of movements as needed. Focus on mobility and pelvic floor prep. Walking becomes primary cardio.

progression_timeline.weeks_13_20: Can maintain moderate intensity if feeling good. Focus on technique.
progression_timeline.weeks_20_28: May need to reduce weight as balance changes and belly grows. Shorter rest periods may be needed.
progression_timeline.weeks_28_36: Reduce intensity further. Focus on mobility, lighter weights, preparation for labor.
progression_timeline.weeks_36_40: Walking, gentle stretching, pelvic floor work. Keep active but light.

additional_recommendations: CRITICAL: Stay hydrated - drink water before, during, and after exercise
Wear supportive sports bra and consider belly support band
Pelvic floor exercises daily - practice relaxation, not just strengthening
Practice deep squats regularly - great for labor positioning
Work on hip mobility - will help with labor and delivery
Maintain good posture throughout day as belly grows
Swimming is excellent low-impact option (avoid hot tubs/hot water)
Walking is perfect safe cardio throughout pregnancy
Listen to your body - what worked last week may not work this week
Consider prenatal yoga for flexibility and breathing practice
Don't exercise to exhaustion - can talk comfortably = good intensity
Avoid core exercises causing 'doming' - this indicates excessive pressure
Work with pelvic floor PT if possible for personalized guidance
warning_signs_stop_immediately: Calf pain or swelling (could indicate blood clot)
benefits_of_prenatal_exercise: Stronger pelvic floor = reduced incontinence risk

medical_condition_workouts_part2.name: Metabolic Health Strength Program
medical_condition_workouts_part2.description: A comprehensive training program optimized for Type 2 diabetes management, focusing on improving insulin sensitivity, glucose control, and overall metabolic health through resistance training and controlled cardiovascular work.
medical_condition_workouts_part2.medical_disclaimer: Consult your physician before starting, especially if you have complications (neuropathy, retinopathy, nephropathy). Monitor blood glucose before and after exercise. Know signs of hypoglycemia. This program complements, not replaces, medical treatment and dietary management.
key_modifications: Monitor blood glucose before and after training
Time training appropriately with meals and medication
Build up intensity gradually to avoid blood sugar spikes/drops
Emphasize compound movements for maximum glucose uptake
Include both resistance training and cardiovascular work
safety_guidelines: Check blood glucose before exercise (safe range: 100-250 mg/dL)
If below 100 mg/dL, eat 15-30g carbs before training
If above 300 mg/dL, delay training and check ketones
Always carry fast-acting carbs (glucose tablets, juice)
Know hypoglycemia signs: shakiness, sweating, confusion, dizziness
Wear medical ID bracelet
Train with a partner or in supervised environment when possible
Inspect feet daily for cuts or sores (especially if neuropathy present)

blood_glucose_management.action: Test blood glucose 30 minutes before training
Consume 15-30g quick carbs, wait 15 min, retest
Check for ketones. If present, DO NOT exercise. If no ketones, can exercise but monitor closely
Test immediately after and 2 hours post-training to understand response

workouts.focus: Major compound movements for metabolic benefit

warm_up.notes: Gentle warm-up. Monitor how you feel.
Leg swings, arm circles, torso rotations

exercises.notes: Squats are EXCELLENT for glucose uptake (large muscle mass). Use moderate weight.
Posterior chain work. Great for metabolic effect.
Upper body push. Builds muscle = better insulin sensitivity.
Upper body pull. Balanced development.
Hamstring isolation. Additional leg work enhances glucose uptake.
Important if you have peripheral neuropathy - strengthens lower legs.
Core stability.

post_workout_cardio.notes: Post-training cardio helps regulate blood sugar. Very effective.

workouts.focus: Cardiovascular health and glucose regulation

options.notes: Walking, cycling, rowing, swimming. Good for insulin sensitivity without depleting glucose too fast.

options.notes: More time-efficient. Monitor blood sugar closely with intervals.

workouts.focus: Different movement patterns, continued metabolic stimulus

workouts.focus: Movement without depleting glucose, promotes recovery

Moderate weight. Total body stability and glucose uptake.

post_workout_cardio.notes: Consistent post-training cardio helps regulate blood sugar response.

exercise_timing_recommendations.optimal_timing: 30-90 minutes after meals (when blood glucose is elevated)
exercise_timing_recommendations.avoid: Exercising during peak insulin action (if on insulin)
exercise_timing_recommendations.morning_training: May need small snack if fasting overnight

why_resistance_training_for_diabetes: Increases muscle mass = more glucose storage capacity
Improves insulin sensitivity for 24-72 hours post-training
Helps control blood sugar better than cardio alone
Prevents sarcopenia (muscle loss) which worsens diabetes
Improves quality of life and independence

progression_timeline.weeks_1_4: Learn movement patterns, establish baseline blood sugar responses, moderate intensity
progression_timeline.weeks_5_8: Increase loads progressively, monitor glucose patterns, adjust nutrition timing
progression_timeline.weeks_9_12: Continue progressive overload, may notice improved insulin sensitivity
progression_timeline.weeks_13_plus: Maintain consistent training, work with healthcare team to potentially adjust medications

additional_recommendations: CRITICAL: Never exercise alone if prone to hypoglycemia
Keep glucose tablets or juice with you at ALL times
Wear diabetic medical ID during training
Track blood glucose before, after, and 2 hours post-training (at least initially)
Work with endocrinologist - may need medication adjustments as fitness improves
Combine exercise with diet management for best results
Inspect feet daily for any cuts, blisters, or sores (especially with neuropathy)
Wear proper athletic shoes - diabetic foot care is critical
Stay hydrated - dehydration affects blood sugar
Get adequate sleep - affects insulin sensitivity
Manage stress - cortisol raises blood glucose
Consistency is more important than intensity - regular moderate exercise beats sporadic intense training
Consider continuous glucose monitor (CGM) to track exercise responses
Resistance training 2-3x/week + daily walking = excellent combination

hypoglycemia_management.treatment: Stop exercise immediately. Consume 15g fast-acting carbs (4 glucose tablets, 4 oz juice, 1 tablespoon honey). Wait 15 min, retest. Repeat if still low. Once stable, eat small meal.
hypoglycemia_management.prevention: Check blood sugar before training, adjust insulin/medication timing with doctor, always carry fast carbs, train with partner

contraindications_modifications.severe_retinopathy: Avoid heavy Valsalva, exercises increasing blood pressure in eyes. No heavy deadlifts or overhead press.
contraindications_modifications.peripheral_neuropathy: Avoid exercises requiring balance if severe. Focus on seated/supported exercises. Careful foot inspection essential.
contraindications_modifications.autonomic_neuropathy: May have abnormal heart rate response. Use RPE instead of heart rate. Stay well hydrated.
contraindications_modifications.kidney_disease: Avoid excessive protein intake. Moderate intensity exercise only. Clear with nephrologist.

medical_condition_workouts_part2.name: Joint-Friendly Strength & Mobility Program
medical_condition_workouts_part2.description: A comprehensive training program for managing osteoarthritis pain while building strength, improving mobility, and maintaining independence. Focuses on controlled loading, strengthening supporting muscles, and pain-free movement patterns.
medical_condition_workouts_part2.medical_disclaimer: This program is for mild to moderate osteoarthritis. If you have severe pain, significant joint deformity, or are considering joint replacement, consult your orthopedic specialist first. Exercise should not cause pain beyond 3/10 during activity that subsides after.
key_modifications: Work within pain-free ranges of motion
Strengthen muscles around affected joints
Emphasize controlled movements over heavy loading
Include low-impact cardiovascular work
Progress gradually - joints need adaptation time
safety_guidelines: Pain should not exceed 3/10 during exercise
Some discomfort is OK, sharp pain is NOT
If pain increases or lasts >2 hours post-exercise, reduce intensity
Warm up thoroughly - cold joints are stiff joints
Ice if needed post-training (15-20 minutes)
Don't exercise during flare-ups - rest and gentle movement only
Movement is medicine - staying active prevents joint stiffening

progression_timeline.weeks_1_4: Establish baseline pain-free ranges, build work capacity, very gradual loading
progression_timeline.weeks_5_8: Slowly increase resistance and volume, may notice improved mobility
progression_timeline.weeks_9_12: Continue progressive overload within pain-free ranges
progression_timeline.weeks_13_plus: Maintain strength training 2-3x/week indefinitely - consistency is key

additional_recommendations: CRITICAL: Exercise is one of the best treatments for osteoarthritis - staying active prevents worsening
Aquatic exercise / swimming is EXCELLENT for arthritis - highly recommended
Maintain healthy weight - every pound of excess weight puts 4 pounds of pressure on knees
Consider glucosamine/chondroitin supplements (discuss with doctor - evidence is mixed)
Heat before exercise (warm-up), ice after if needed
Use supportive footwear with good cushioning
Consider knee sleeves or braces for additional support during training
Physical therapy can provide personalized exercise prescription
Anti-inflammatory medication as directed by doctor
Foam rolling and massage can help surrounding muscles
Walking aids (cane, walker) when needed - no shame in using support
Resistance training builds muscles that support joints - crucial for arthritis management
Some discomfort during exercise is normal - pain that persists or worsens is NOT
Regular exercise can delay or prevent need for joint replacement surgery
Consistency beats intensity - moderate exercise done regularly is the goal
when_to_see_doctor: Pain that doesn't improve with rest and ice
Significant swelling or warmth in joint
Significant reduction in range of motion
Pain that interferes with sleep or daily activities
If considering injections (corticosteroid, hyaluronic acid) or surgery
benefits_of_exercise_for_arthritis: Improves balance and reduces fall risk
Increases independence and quality of life
